questions.text: You prescribe oral rehydration solution (ORS) to a child brought to the outpatient department with complaints of loose stools. ORS facilitates glucose absorption through sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter-1 (SGLT-1). This glucose co-transport with sodium ions is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Glucose co-transported with sodium is an example of secondary active transport.

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. As one of the substances (e.g., sodium) diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, energy is released, which is used to drive another substance (e.g., glucose) against the gradient. Thus, secondary active transport does not require energy directly from ATP.
 
Sodium ions are transported out of cells by primary active transport, resulting in a large concentration gradient across the cell membrane. This gradient represents a storehouse of energy, which is used by sodium to pull glucose along with it using the SGLT-1 transporter. This phenomenon, called co- transport, is one form of secondary active transport. 

Types of transport:

  • Active transport
    • Primary
      • Energy is derived from ATP.
      • Example: Na+ K+ ATPase pump.
    • Secondary:
      • Energy is derived indirectly (ion gradient).
      • Example: Sodium linked glucose transport in kidneys and intestine, Sodium linked iodine transport
  • Passive transport
    • Simple:
      • No energy is required.
      • No carrier molecule is involved.
      • Eg. O2 exchange in alveoli.
    • Facilitated:
      • No energy is required.
      • Carrier molecule involved.
      • Eg. Glucose transport by GLUT transporters.

questions.text: You are providing cardiopulmonary resuscitation to an unconscious adult patient. Which of the following statements correctly describes effective chest compressions?

choices.text: Full chest recoil is avoided between 2 compressions
The chest is pressed to a depth of 4 inches
Given at lower half of the sternum

questions.solution:
Effective chest compressions in BLS are given on the lower half of the patient's sternum at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).

Adequate chest compressions create blood flow by increasing the intrathoracic pressure and directly compressing the heart.

2015 AHA guidelines for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) recommend a chest compression of 100-120/min, a depth for adults of at least 2 inches. 

Components of high-quality CPR include compressing the chest at an adequate rate and depth. Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression. Minimizing interruptions in compressions and should avoid excessive ventilation.

Effective chest compression in adults:

  • Provide 15 chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute.
  • Place your arms, one over the other in the midline, on the lower half of the patient's sternum, and lock your arms.
  • Use both arms to press the chest to a depth of 5- 6cm
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: The  Secretomotor fibers to the structure marked green in the image pass through which of the following ganglion?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the parotid gland and the secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland pass through the otic ganglion.

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent total hip replacement surgery 4 days back. She is advised to wear compression stockings for the prevention of a particular condition.  Which of the following is true regarding this particular condition?

choices.text: Clinical assessment is reliable in establishing the diagnosis
Pain and swelling in the calf are most common presentations
Inflammatory bowel disease is protective against developing this condition

questions.solution:
The patient is provided with a pair of compression stockings to prevent the occurrence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Pain and swelling in the calf are the most common presentations of DVT. 

Clinical features of DVT include:

  • Fever 
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf.
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s, or Neuhof’s signs.
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Features of pulmonary embolism such as pulmonary hypertension, dyspnea ad pleuritic chest pain
  • It may be asymptomatic

Most cases of DVT are unilateral. Bilateral cases are seen in 30% of individuals. DVT commonly occurs in pelvis veins and leg veins such as femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side). Inflammatory bowel disease is a risk factor for the development of DVT. 

The clinical examination may be unreliable in establishing the diagnosis. Venous duplex ultrasound is commonly performed to look for evidence of thrombosis throughout the deep or superficial venous system.  Ascending venography may be rarely required unless thrombolysis is being considered. MR venography may also be used. In the case of a pulmonary embolus, a definitive diagnosis can be done by CT pulmonary angiogram.

Treatment includes:

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with a crepe bandage
  • Anticoagulants - heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione
  • Thrombolysis, endovenous thrombectomy, and stenting to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

questions.text: A carpenter presented with irritation and blurring of vision in both eyes for 1 week. A wooden piece penetrated into his right eye 4 weeks back while working. On evaluation, the visual acuity of the left eye was 6/12 and there is only perception of light in his right eye. Fundoscopic examination revealed subretinal deposits corresponding to Dalen-Fuch's nodules. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with bilateral redness and irritation, subretinal deposits corresponding to Dalenn Fusch nodules on fundoscopy, and a history of ocular trauma likely has sympathetic ophthalmitis. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to delayed type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk. It presents between 2 weeks and 3 months after the inciting event in trauma-induced cases. 

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Clinical features include redness and irritation in the "exciting eye", and irritation, photophobia, and loss of accommodation in the "sympathizing eye". Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and the severity of inflammation is markedly different in both eyes. 

Fundus examination will reveal exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis, and optic disc swelling. Dalen Fuch's nodules are local granulomas due to the proliferation of lymphocytes and epithelioid cells and are located between RPE and Bruch's membrane.

Investigations include optical coherence tomography, B scan ultrasonography, fluorescein angiography, and ultrasound.

Treatment mainly involves steroids. High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to the response. Immunosuppressant drugs such as methotrexate, cyclosporine, and azathioprine can be used as steroid-sparing agents, or in resistant cases.

Historically, enucleation of the injured eye if performed soon after the injury has been shown to reduce the incidence. However, with advancing surgical techniques, an increasing number of traumatically injured eyes are deemed to be salvageable.

questions.text: A patient develops hemolytic anemia following the consumption of fava beans. After a detailed workup, she is found to have a condition that is due to a defect in a metabolic pathway. In which of the following sites does this pathway occur?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the deficiency of the G6PD (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) enzyme. It is an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway or the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt pathway which occurs in the cytosol.

G6PD is an enzyme that plays a critical role in redox reactions that occur in all aerobic cells. It is the only source of NADPH in erythrocytes that helps in the formation of reduced glutathione. This reduced form protects erythrocytes against oxidative stress.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked inheritance disorder. Most patients with this condition are asymptomatic. But when exposed to oxidative agents, they are prone to develop acute hemolytic anemia. The various oxidative triggers include:

  • Fava beans
  • Infections
  • Drugs such as primaquine, dapsone, and nitrofurantoin

A hemolytic attack can present with weakness and abdominal/ lumbar pain. Later, the patient can develop jaundice, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria. Investigations will show elevated levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and low levels of plasma haptoglobin. Acute renal failure is a complication seen in adults.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with chest pain and difficulty in swallowing for the past 8 months. A High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal esophagus and absent peristalsis. What is the best management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture points towards achalasia cardia, for which the treatment of choice is laparoscopic Heller's myotomy + Dor fundoplication.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. This is due to the loss of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus. Based on the manometric findings it can be classified into 3 types.

Diagnosis is established by high-resolution oesophageal manometry which shows

  • Absent peristalsis.
  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation.
  • Raised esophageal resting pressure.
  • LOS pressure may be elevated, but is often normal.

Treatment of achalasia cardia:

Non-surgical:

  • Medical management with sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, and calcium-channel blockers for symptomatic relief.
  • Pneumatic dilatation
  • Botox injection

Surgical—Treatment of choice

  • Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the definitive management - The major complication associated with this procedure is gastro-oesophageal reflux. So it is best to combine it with partial anterior fundoplication (Heller–Dor operation).
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a recently introduced, advanced natural-orifice approach for myotomy.
  • Open Esophageal Myotomy - rarely done. 

Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM).

 

Option A: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is used to treat infantile pyloric stenosis.

Option B: Dohlman's procedure is the treatment of choice in Zenker's diverticulum.

Option C: Nissen's fundoplication is total fundoplication done in GERD

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 12-month-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and difficulty in breathing. On examination, the child had biphasic stridor. Which of the following level is affected to produce this type of stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of subglottis (marked as 3) will cause biphasic stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the dermatology clinic with complaints of reddish-pink nodules on her thighs. The mother is worried about it being a tumor. A sample is sent for histopathological examination and the findings are shown below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child with reddish-pink nodules and histopathological findings showing large fusiform plump naevomelanocytes(spindled and/or epitheloid naevomelanocytes) is highly suggestive of the spitz nevus (spindle and epithelioid cell nevus), a variant of melanocytic nevus.

A spitz nevus is a melanocytic lesion characterized by spindled and/or epitheloid naevomelanocytes. It is Commonly seen in children as a red-pink nodule, often confused with hemangioma clinically. The classic Spitz naevus usually appears as a solitary, firm, symmetrical, sharply demarcated, round or dome‐shaped nodule of around 5–6 mm in diameter. The color of the lesion is pink to red to reddish brown.

Histologically it can be hard to distinguish spitz nevus from melanoma, they are benign lesions with favorable prognosis. Naevomelanocytic(spindled and/or epitheloid cells) nests are neatly located between keratinocytes, unlike their disorderly arrangement in melanoma.

Melanocytic nevi (moles) are common benign neoplasms caused by acquired activating mutations in components of the Ras signaling pathway.

Based on the location, it may be junctional nevi, intradermal nevi, or compound nevi. 

Other Options:

Option B: Infantile hemangioma is a common benign vascular tumor in childhood. It presents anywhere on the body and is usually not present at birth. They appear red or maroon if superficial, and bluish if deep. They regress by 4 years of age usually. It is shown in the image below.

Option C: Becker’s nevus presents as a hyperpigmented, hypertrichosis patch on the upper trunk and usually begins just before puberty. It is shown below.

Option D- Nevus of Ota is a blue-black macule usually present since birth. Conjunctiva, sclera, and skin supplied by the trigeminal nerve are the most common site involved. They are present throughout life.

The below image shows the nevus of Ota.

questions.text: A male baby was brought to the pediatrician in the 5th week of life with complaints of non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A mass could be palpated in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows the following. Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign on ultrasound is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hence the ABG which shows a pH: 7.48, pCO2: 47, HCO3: 30 is the answer.

A pH >7.40, with increased HCO3, and increased pCO2 indicate metabolic alkalosis.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs seen on USG.

  • Nipple sign- Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach
  • Cervix sign- The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: An army major was held as a captive of war and was rescued 5 months ago. He presented with a history of recurrent nightmares and flashbacks about being held captive for the past 4 months. He also complains of chronic pain, fatigue, recurrent feelings of failure and guilt.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder.

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterised by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event. Examples include witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disasters, life-threatening illness, and physical or sexual abuse. 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms - flashbacks - the individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring, nightmares
  • Hyperarousal - increased startle response, insomnia, hypervigilance, self-destructive behavior, irritability, and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms - avoiding memories, thoughts, feelings, and external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event

The duration of these symptoms should be >1 month to label it as PTSD.

Based on the duration between the event and the presentation of symptoms, stress disorder is classified as follows.

Duration Condition
3 days to 1 month Acute stress reaction
More than 1 month Post-traumatic stress disorder
Symptoms occur after 6 months of the stressor event Delayed Post-traumatic stress disorder

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioural therapy, and eye movement desensitisation. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

questions.text: A lady at 24 weeks of gestation comes for a regular antenatal workup. Her previous antenatal checkups are normal. A 75 g oral glucose tolerance test shows her 2-hour postprandial blood sugar values to be 180 mg/dL. Which of the following steps of management is not indicated in this condition?

choices.text: Insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents can be used in treatment
Routine labor induction should be done at 37 weeks
Prophylactic cesarean may be considered if fetal weight is > 4500 g

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gestational diabetes mellitus and routine labour induction at 37 weeks is not indicated.

Gestational diabetes is carbohydrate intolerance that is first diagnosed/recognized during pregnancy. This condition is managed expectantly. According to the ACOG guidelines, patients with diet-treated GDM are not induced until 39 weeks and insulin-treated patients are typically delivered at 38 weeks of gestation.

Pregnant women are universally screened between 24 and 28 weeks for gestational diabetes mellitus.

The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group (IADPSG) recommends a single-step approach of a 75g 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) for screening. Gestational diabetes is diagnosed if the fasting blood glucose value crosses the threshold of 92 mg/dL. Another screening approach is the two-step approach with a 50-g screening test followed by 100-g 3-hour OGTT.

Other options:

Option A: Treatment using hypoglycemic drugs is recommended in patients who cannot maintain fasting blood glucose levels to <95 mg/dL or 2-hour postprandial glucose levels to <120 mg/dL despite being on dietary modifications. Insulin is the preferred treatment as it does not cross the placenta and a tighter glycemic control can be achieved. Oral hypoglycemic agents such as metformin and glyburide can also be used.

Option C: Prophylactic cesarean delivery may be considered if the fetal weight is estimated to be >4500 g.

Option D: Since diabetic mothers are prone to having a fetus with congenital cardiac anomalies, 2nd-trimester fetal echocardiography is done as it is an essential indicator for birth defects.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A patient was given metoclopramide for severe vomiting.  After which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. The observed adverse effects are due to?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient has developed extrapyramidal adverse effects like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. This is likely due to the antagonist action on dopamine receptors by metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and antiemetic. It has the following pharmacological actions:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle. This results in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antral contractions.

Metoclopramide acts on both the gastrointestinal system and central nervous system. It is used as an upper antiemetic for many types of vomiting, especially migraine, drug-induced, and chemotherapy-induced. It is also used as a prokinetic in gastroparesis to increase gastric emptying.

Adverse effects of metoclopramide are mainly extrapyramidal effects, and these include acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuation of metoclopramide and administration of anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was assaulted by his neighbor during an argument. The assailant has admitted that he did assault the victim but did not cause any injury. Which section of the Indian penal code (IPC) can be applied to the assailant?
questions.solution:
The description of the crime fits with assault and the section applicable is section 351 of the IPC.

Section 351 of the IPC - This section defines assault as applying or even attempting to apply force to the body of another individual in a hostile manner. This section can be applied irrespective of whether the assault causes any injury or not. Even hostile gestures such as raising a fist at someone in a hostile manner can constitute assault. Sections 352 to 358 IPC deal with punishments for various types of assaults.

Other options :

Option A- Section 300 of the IPC- This section applies to murder.

Option B- Section 307 of the IPC- This section is applicable in cases of attempt to murder.

Option D- Section 320 of the IPC- This section defines grievous hurt or injury which includes injuries such as:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

questions.text: The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by:
questions.solution:
The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C. This is called the Reynold Braude phenomenon.

The image given below shows germ tube formation seen in candida species.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; and Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata.  Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with a history of fall on a flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the forearm. On examination, there is tenderness and painful dorsiflexion of the wrist. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements are false about this condition?

choices.text: Unstable fractures are fixed with percutaneous pins or small screws
Conservative management is done with short arm cast
They are best seen on lateral view

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the X-ray showing the dorsal segment of distal radius fracture extending into the intra-articular region is suggestive of dorsal Barton's fracture. Barton's fractures are invariably intra-articular fractures. 

Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. The dorsal or volar rim of the distal radius can be involved and they are named accordingly.

Dorsal Barton:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the dorsal rim of the distal radius. It is caused due to falling on the flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the distal forearm. These fractures are best seen on the lateral view and the radiograph shows proximal and posterior displacement of the dorsal lip of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management is by short arm cast with the wrist in the neutral position. Surgical management is by open reduction and internal fixation with percutaneous pins or small plates and screws.

Volar Barton/Palmar rim dislocation:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the anterior/palmar rim of the distal radius. It is caused by palmar tensile stress and dorsal shear stress and may be associated with radial styloid fractures. The radiograph shows dorsal displacement of the palmar rim of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management - long-arm cast. Even though reduction is simple, retention is usually difficult. Surgical fixation with K- wires, external fixators, and buttress plates are considered if the reduction is not properly retained. Ellis-T-shaped buttress plate fixation is mostly preferred.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: During your rural posting in a district that is endemic for Japanese encephalitis, a 6-year-old completely unimmunized child was brought to your Primary Health Center. Which of the following vaccines can be given to this child now?
questions.solution:
Among the given options DPT-1 and JE-1 can be given to a 6-year-old child who is completely unimmunized for the age. 

For an unvaccinated child between the age of 5-7 years, the first, second, and third doses of the DPT vaccine are given at one-month intervals. The booster dose can be given at a minimum of 6 months after administering the third dose of DPT up to 7 years of age.

JE vaccine can be given to a child from an endemic district for Japanese encephalitis up to 15 years of age. 

BCG vaccine is given up to 1 year of age. This is because most of the children acquire natural clinical/sub-clinical tuberculosis infection by the age of one year. This will also protect against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis.

OPV can only be given up to 5 years of age.

Vaccines that can be given to an unvaccinated child between the age of 1 - 5 years are DPT-1, OPV-1, measles, and 2 mL of vitamin A. At one-month intervals, second and third doses of DPT and OPV should be given. The second dose of measles is given as per the schedule. OPV/DPT booster dose can be given at a minimum of 6 months after administering their third dose.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with thunderclap headaches and seizures. There is no history of trauma. Non-contrast CT was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a thunderclap headache and seizures with the given CT scan showing hyperdense areas corresponding to blood in the subarachnoid basal cisterns suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

Patients present with a sudden and severe headache referred to as thunderclap headache, which may be associated with vomiting, decreased consciousness, and seizures. Neck stiffness and photophobia may develop after a few hours.

Non-contrast CT scan is the imaging modality of choice if done within 12 hours. It shows an increased density of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. A lumbar puncture should be done if there is a strong suspicion of SAH but negative CT findings. It is ideally done 12 hours later. This allows for red blood cell lysis to occur and bilirubin to be detected in the CSF.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. He is complaining of breathlessness for the past 3 days. A chest radiograph was taken and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region. This finding along with the CD4 count of 170 cells /μL makes pneumocystis pneumonia as the most likely diagnosis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

The classic radiographic appearance of symptomatic pneumocystis pneumonia consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Histopathology of the tissue will show foamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP. Specific stains like methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa can show the cysts. Other tests which are used for the diagnosis of PCP are polymerase chain reaction, (1→3)-β-d-glucan, etc.

The treatment and prevention of PCP are with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Other options

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

Below image- Consolidation in streptococcal pneumonia

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of hematuria and hemoptysis. His renal biopsy showed crescentic glomerular lesions suggestive of RPGN. Immunofluorescence findings are given in the image below. Which type of RPGN is this condition classified as?

RPGN - Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence showing a linear, smooth diffuse pattern of staining is suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome, which is classified under type I RPGN.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity with features of nephritic syndrome and rapid loss of renal function. It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents, but it does not denote a specific etiologic form of glomerulonephritis.

In most cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. Circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in the pauci-immune type of RPGN. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes

Based on immunologic findings, RPGN is classified as:

Anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease (Type I) is characterized by linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence and includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. Here, the antibodies are produced against a peptide present in the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM. This serves as the antigen which is common to the alveoli and the glomerulus.

Immune complex deposition (Type II) is characterized by granular deposits of antibodies and complement on immunofluorescence and can be a complication of any of the immune complex nephritides which include:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura

Pauci-immune (Type III) exhibits no characteristic immunoglobulin or complement deposits on immunofluorescence. It includes

  • ANCA-associated
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease affecting men more than women, with simultaneous hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis and rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis. The GBM antigen is a component of the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen, which is common to both alveoli and glomeruli.

On microscopy, the renal biopsy shows show linear GBM fluorescence for Ig and complement. Electron microscopy (EM) shows the wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.
